subject: Re: [junit] Re: Any plans to revamp junit?
msgSnippet: ... One practical implication is this: the longer JUnit stays frozen/moribound with known issues (such as classloading and test collation) the more likely it
messageBody:
Ilja Preuss wrote:


> With all due respect, that's my general impression of this thread - that
> it's more about the philospical issues of managing an open source
> project than about the practical implications.

One practical implication is this: the longer JUnit stays
frozen/moribound with known issues (such as classloading and test
collation) the more likely it is to get forked. I really don't care
about features per se, but I do care about forks on a key OS project
due to the project being effectively abandoned by its committers.


> You might disagree with how Junit development is managed, but I think
> until now it has served the community quite well.

It's not 'managed' at all.


> The "slowness" might
> well have prevented it to become bloated with all kinds of shiny
> features which now instead are available as seperate extensions...

Sorry but this argument to slowness is bunk. Saying Junit is stuck
on 3.8.1 because of a concern for featuritis isn't credible imo.

cheers
Bill
